The New Digital Age: Reshaping the Futur.author: Eric Schmidt
reviews: "An incisive analysis of how the age of technology affects everything"

New Rules for the New Economy\tKevin Kel.title: New Rules for the New Economy
New Rules for the New Economy\tKevin Kel.author: Kevin Kelly
reviews: "An essential book when Kevin Kelly published it more than a decade ago, and even more essential now. Ignore its lessons at your peril."

Nights at the Circus\tAngela Carter.title: Nights at the Circus
Nights at the Circus\tAngela Carter.author: Angela Carter
reviews: "Perhaps Angela Carter's finest novel, in which her gorgeous, antic language—part-mythic, part-vaudevillian—richly evokes her greatest heroine."

Noble Savages: My Life Among Two Dangero.title: Noble Savages: My Life Among Two Dangerous Tribes -- the Yanomamo and the Anthropologists
Noble Savages: My Life Among Two Dangero.author: Napoleon Chagnon
reviews: "The Yanomamö Indians of Brazil and Venezuela have become famous for their fierceness and their wars. Chagnon vividly describes his decades of fieldwork among them and the attacks of some anthropologists and a journalist upon his findings"

The Nonexistent Knight and The Cloven Vi.title: The Nonexistent Knight and The Cloven Viscount
The Nonexistent Knight and The Cloven Vi.author: Italo Calvino
reviews: "This is a fable, set in the time of Charlemagne, about an empty suit of armor that believes itself to be a knight and keeps itself going by willpower and strict adherence to the rules of chivalry. The other fables in Calvino's Our Ancestors trilogy are just as good."

One World: The Ethics of Globalization\t.title: One World: The Ethics of Globalization
One World: The Ethics of Globalization\t.author: Peter Singer
reviews: "This is a relatively small book but with a very big idea. I like to use it to test my students’ intuition about the ethical basis for globalisation. Singer makes a simple and, on the face of it, very plausible point which is that the extent to which we care for other human beings shouldn’t depend on what side of the border they live."

Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth\tBu.title: Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth
Operating Manual for Spaceship Earth\tBu.author: Buckminster Fuller
reviews: "This is the biggest little book I know, jamming the grandest ideas of the 20th century's greatest designer into just 120 pages of conversational text. In brief, our problems are not laws of nature, but artifacts of bad design decisions. And we can change them."

p53: The Gene that Cracked the Cancer Co.title: p53: The Gene that Cracked the Cancer Code
p53: The Gene that Cracked the Cancer Co.author: Sue Armstrong
reviews: "[A fabulous chance] to eavesdrop on science in the making — to be in a ringside seat when great insights into the natural world fall into place."

The Palm at the End of the Mind: Selecte.title: The Palm at the End of the Mind: Selected Poems and a Play
The Palm at the End of the Mind: Selecte.author: Wallace Stevens
reviews: "Stevens is my favorite poet, and this is the most commonly available collection of his poems. His meditations on the relationship of language and reality have entranced me for more than thirty years. I keep reading the same poems, and finding more and more in them."

The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less\.title: The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less
The Paradox of Choice: Why More Is Less\.author: Barry Schwartz
reviews: "Clearly this is not for scholars as it is extremely diluted and slow at times; this is a popular science book. Still, I could not put it down."

The Party: The Secret World of China’s C.title: The Party: The Secret World of China’s Communist Rulers
The Party: The Secret World of China’s C.author: Richard McGregor
reviews: "I am enamored of all things Chinese, so McGregor’s book—subtitled The Secret World of China’s Communist Rulers—was always going to grab my attention. He provides a peek behind the Red Curtain at the political structures that make China tick. The book reveals just how little we really know about Chinese politics."

Pedro Páramo\tJuan Rulfo.title: Pedro Páramo
Pedro Páramo\tJuan Rulfo.author: Juan Rulfo
reviews: "Jorge Luis Borges thought this short, hypnotic novel to be one of the best ever written, and Gabriel García Márquez said it freed him to imagine the world of One Hundred Years of Solitude. A man is told by his dying mother to go find his father. He embarks on the journey and falls into a nightmarish world that may be populated entirely by ghosts."

A People's History of the United States\.title: A People's History of the United States
A People's History of the United States\.author: Howard Zinn

Phi: A Voyage from the Brain to the Soul.title: Phi: A Voyage from the Brain to the Soul
Phi: A Voyage from the Brain to the Soul.author: Giulio Tononi

The Symposium\tPlato.title: The Symposium
The Symposium\tPlato.author: Plato
The Symposium\tPlato.summary: "The Symposium is a philosophical text by Plato dated c. 385–370 BC. It concerns itself at one level with the genesis, purpose and nature of love, and is the origin of the concept of Platonic love."

Pluto's Republic: Incorporating The Art.title: Pluto's Republic: Incorporating The Art of the Soluble and Induction and Intuition in Scientific Thought
Pluto's Republic: Incorporating The Art.author: Peter Medawar
Pluto's Republic: Incorporating The Art.summary: "Essays exploring the nature of science include discussions of topics, such as psychoanalysis, evolution, genetics, and the role of imagination in scientific discoveries."
reviews: "A winner of the Nobel Prize for medicine, Peter Medawar is also the foremost scientific essayist of the 20th century, with the sort of wit that makes you want to seize his book and rush out into the street to show somebody — anybody."

The Politics of Heroin: CIA Complicity i.title: The Politics of Heroin: CIA Complicity in the Global Drug Trade
The Politics of Heroin: CIA Complicity i.author: Alfred W. McCoy
The Politics of Heroin: CIA Complicity i.summary: "The first book to prove CIA and U.S. government complicity in global drug trafficking, The Politics of Heroin includes meticulous documentation of dishonesty and dirty dealings at the highest levels from the Cold War until today."

Positioning: The Battle for Your Mind\tA.title: Positioning: The Battle for Your Mind
Positioning: The Battle for Your Mind\tA.author: Al Ries
Positioning: The Battle for Your Mind\tA.summary: "The first book to deal with the problems of communicating to a skeptical, media-blitzed public, Positioning describes a revolutionary approach to creating a 'position' in a prospective customer's mind-one that reflects a company's own strengths and weaknesses as well as those of its competitors."
reviews: "Anyone who wants to start a business with impact needs to read [this]."

The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do.title: The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business
The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do.author: Charles Duhigg
The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do.summary: "In The Power of Habit, Pulitzer Prize–winning business reporter Charles Duhigg takes us to the thrilling edge of scientific discoveries that explain why habits exist and how they can be changed."
reviews: "Here's something lighter — ideas you can use! Duhigg's examination of how people get caught in loops of frequently counterproductive behavior is entertaining and can help you develop good habits. Who doesn't need that?"

Praise of Folly\tErasmus.title: Praise of Folly
Praise of Folly\tErasmus.author: Erasmus
Praise of Folly\tErasmus.summary: "Erasmus ranges from light-hearted jibes to vehement denunciation of the theologians and churchmen, monastic life and the condition of the Church, and then seriously expounds the virtues of the Christian way of life."
reviews: “He shows how we all, particularly Christians, should try to laugh at ourselves and love others.”

A Preponderance of Power: National Secur.title: A Preponderance of Power: National Security, the Truman Administration, and the Cold War
A Preponderance of Power: National Secur.author: Melvyn Leffler
A Preponderance of Power: National Secur.summary: "While many historians used [the era's declassified] records to explore specialized topics, this author marshals the considerable available evidence on behalf of an overall analysis of national security policy during the Truman years. To date, it is the most comprehensive history of that administration's progressive embroilment in the Cold War."

Prisoner's Dilemma\tWilliam Poundstone.title: Prisoner's Dilemma
Prisoner's Dilemma\tWilliam Poundstone.author: William Poundstone
Prisoner's Dilemma\tWilliam Poundstone.summary: "A masterful work of science writing, Prisoner's Dilemma weaves together a biography of the brilliant and tragic von Neumann, a history of pivotal phases of the cold war, and an investigation of game theory's far-reaching influence on public policy."

Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American.title: Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American Power
Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American.author: Steve Coll
Private Empire: ExxonMobil and American.summary: "In this, the first hard-hitting examination of ExxonMobil—the largest and most powerful private corporation in the United States—Steve Coll reveals the true extent of its power."
reviews: "Which will give you a long list of other reasons why Exxon is a very dodgy outfit."

The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a.title: The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a Justified Sinner
The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a.author: James Hogg
The Private Memoirs and Confessions of a.summary: "An enigmatic figure by the name of Gil-Martin convinces Robert that he is an Elect - a soul bound to go to Heaven no matter the deeds in life. How will Robert choose to live the rest of his days? As a pious and modest man waiting for his Heavenly reward or as an despotic, vile and sinful person?"
reviews: "Everything you want to know about the split personality of Calvinism. It gave me a distinctly uncomfortable insight into my own predicament. A sense of belonging to the predestined godly elect doesn’t necessarily make you a nice person."

The Psychopath: Emotion and the Brain\tJ.title: The Psychopath: Emotion and the Brain
The Psychopath: Emotion and the Brain\tJ.author: James Blair
The Psychopath: Emotion and the Brain\tJ.summary: "Psychopaths continue to be demonised by the media and estimates suggest that a disturbing percentage of the population has psychopathic tendencies. This timely and controversial new book summarises what we already know about psychopathy and antisocial behavior and puts forward a new case for its cause - with far-reaching implications."

The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through t.title: The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through the Madness Industry
The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through t.author: Jon Ronson
The Psychopath Test: A Journey Through t.summary: "They say one out of every hundred people is a psychopath. You probably passed one on the street today. These are people who have no empathy, who are manipulative, deceitful, charming, seductive, and delusional. The Psychopath Test is the New York Times bestselling exploration of their world and the madness industry."

The Quran Speaks\tBahis Sedq.title: The Quran Speaks
The Quran Speaks\tBahis Sedq.author: Bahis Sedq
The Quran Speaks\tBahis Sedq.summary: "The author was raised in the liberal tradition of Islam. He therefore found it difficult to come to terms, as do most moderate Muslims, with how a message of absolute peace and forgiveness could be so distorted by the militant fundamentalists. It was to counter views associated with the less tolerant schools of thought that he was first drawn into reading and understanding the Quran. This book is the outcome."
reviews: "A hugely important book by a scholar of Islam who is, to my mind, the most sophisticated of all the dissidents in the Muslim world. The tragedy is that he has to publish under a pseudonym. He could be the Muslim Luther, if there were only a way to keep him safe."

Race Against The Machine: How the Digita.title: Race Against The Machine: How the Digital Revolution is Accelerating Innovation, Driving Productivity, and Irreversibly Transforming Employment and the Economy
Race Against The Machine: How the Digita.author: Erik Brynjolfsson
Race Against The Machine: How the Digita.summary: "In Race Against the Machine Brynjolfsson and McAfee bring together a range of statistics, examples, and arguments to show that the average worker is not keeping up with cutting-edge technologies, and so is losing the race against the machine. The book makes the case that employment prospects are grim for many today not because there’s been technology has stagnated, but instead because we humans and our organizations aren’t keeping up."

The Rational Optimist: How Prosperity Ev.title: The Rational Optimist: How Prosperity Evolves
The Rational Optimist: How Prosperity Ev.author: Matt Ridley
The Rational Optimist: How Prosperity Ev.summary: "In a bold and provocative interpretation of economic history, Matt Ridley, the New York Times-bestselling author of Genome and The Red Queen, makes the case for an economics of hope, arguing that the benefits of commerce, technology, innovation, and change—what Ridley calls cultural evolution—will inevitably increase human prosperity."
reviews: “A brilliant look at a naturalistic view of civilization, its treasures and problems. I don’t agree with all of it, but it is surprisingly clear and well-argued.”

Reagan Versus The Sandinistas: The Undec.title: Reagan Versus The Sandinistas: The Undeclared War On Nicaragua
Reagan Versus The Sandinistas: The Undec.author: Thomas W. Walker
Reagan Versus The Sandinistas: The Undec.summary: "Even at [thirty] years this extensive and complete study tells us much about the development of our present US foreign policy and its manipulation of public opinion through lies and of its vast cruelty to entire foreign populations under our dirty wars."

The Really Hard Problem: Meaning in a Ma.title: The Really Hard Problem: Meaning in a Material World
The Really Hard Problem: Meaning in a Ma.author: Owen Flanagan
The Really Hard Problem: Meaning in a Ma.summary: "If consciousness is 'the hard problem' in mind science -- explaining how the amazing private world of consciousness emerges from neuronal activity -- then 'the really hard problem,' writes Owen Flanagan in this provocative book, is explaining how meaning is possible in the material world."
reviews: “A look at ethics from the point of view of naturalism. What can a sober, scientifically minded thinker make of right and wrong, good and evil, and the meaning of life?”

Rethinking Modernity and National Identi.title: Rethinking Modernity and National Identity in Turkey
Rethinking Modernity and National Identi.author: Sibel Bozdogan
Rethinking Modernity and National Identi.summary: "The essays in this book are the first attempt to examine the Turkish experiment with modernity from a broad, interdisciplinary perspective, encompassing the fields of history, the social sciences, the humanities, architecture, and urban planning."
reviews: "This is a rich, thought-provoking collection for anyone interested in the construction of a nation-state and the Turkish experiment with modernity. "

In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons o.title: In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam
In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons o.author: Robert S. McNamara
In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons o.summary: "McNamara's controversial book tells the inside and personal story of America's descent into Vietnam from a unique point of view, and is one of the most enlightening books about government ever written."

Romeo & Juliet\tWilliam Shakespeare.title: Romeo & Juliet
Romeo & Juliet\tWilliam Shakespeare.author: William Shakespeare
Romeo & Juliet\tWilliam Shakespeare.summary: "Romeo and Juliet was the first drama in English to confer full tragic dignity on the agonies of youthful love. The lyricism that enshrines their death-marked devotion has made the lovers legendary in every language that possesses a literature."
reviews: "[What are your favorite works of pure fiction?]"

The Rule of Nobody: Saving America from.title: The Rule of Nobody: Saving America from Dead Laws and Broken Government
The Rule of Nobody: Saving America from.author: Philip K. Howard
The Rule of Nobody: Saving America from.summary: "In The Rule of Nobody Philip K. Howard argues for a return to the framers’ vision of public law―setting goals and boundaries, not dictating daily choices. This incendiary book explains how America went wrong and offers a guide for how to liberate human ingenuity to meet the challenges of this century."

Safe for Democracy: The Anglo-American R.title: Safe for Democracy: The Anglo-American Response to Revolution, 1913-1923
Safe for Democracy: The Anglo-American R.author: Lloyd C. Gardner
Safe for Democracy: The Anglo-American R.summary: "This ground-breaking book probes the way that two capitalist superpowers, Great Britain and the United States, responded to the momentous challenge of revolution that emerged during the early years of [the 20th] century."

Science and Sanity: An Introduction to N.title: Science and Sanity: An Introduction to Non-Aristotelian Systems and General Semantics
Science and Sanity: An Introduction to N.author: Alfred Korzybski
Science and Sanity: An Introduction to N.summary: "The original work by Alfred Korzybski introducing the field of general semantics."
reviews: "OK, General Semantics was the 30s equivalent of pop-psychology in the 70s, but there are some great concepts there. 'The map is not the territory.' The idea is that people get stuck in concepts and don't go back to observation."

In Search of Civilization: Remaking a Ta.title: In Search of Civilization: Remaking a Tarnished Idea
In Search of Civilization: Remaking a Ta.author: John Armstrong
In Search of Civilization: Remaking a Ta.summary: "As he roams from anecdote to aesthetic appreciation―from the banality of an early job at an insurance company to the redemptive wonders of a seventeenth-century church spire visible out an office window, from Adam Smith's philosophy to the Japanese tea ceremony―Armstrong reminds us that culture lies within us and that its nourishment is essential to a flourishing society."

The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress,.title: The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress, and Prosperity in a Time of Brilliant Technologies
The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress,.author: Erik Brynjolfsson
The Second Machine Age: Work, Progress,.summary: "In The Second Machine Age MIT’s Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee―two thinkers at the forefront of their field―reveal the forces driving the reinvention of our lives and our economy. As the full impact of digital technologies is felt, we will realize immense bounty in the form of dazzling personal technology, advanced infrastructure, and near-boundless access to the cultural items that enrich our lives."

In the Shadow of Man\tJane Goodall.title: In the Shadow of Man
In the Shadow of Man\tJane Goodall.author: Jane Goodall
In the Shadow of Man\tJane Goodall.summary: "World-renowned primatologist, conservationist, and humanitarian Dr. Jane Goodall’s account of her life among the wild chimpanzees of Gombe is one of the most enthralling stories of animal behavior ever written."
reviews: "The classic study of our closest relative, the chimpanzee."

Shadows of the Mind: A Search for the Mi.title: Shadows of the Mind: A Search for the Missing Science of Consciousness
Shadows of the Mind: A Search for the Mi.author: Roger Penrose
Shadows of the Mind: A Search for the Mi.summary: "Penrose offers [an] exhilarating look at modern science as he mounts an even more powerful attack on artificial intelligence. But perhaps more important, in this volume he points the way to a new science, one that may eventually explain the physical basis of the human mind."

A Significant Life: Human Meaning in a S.title: A Significant Life: Human Meaning in a Silent Universe
A Significant Life: Human Meaning in a S.author: Todd May
A Significant Life: Human Meaning in a S.summary: "What makes for a good life, or a beautiful one, or, perhaps most important, a meaningful one? Throughout history most of us have looked to our faith, our relationships, or our deeds for the answer. But in A Significant Life, philosopher Todd May offers an exhilarating new way of thinking about these questions, one deeply attuned to life as it actually is: a work in progress, a journey—and often a narrative."

Six Not-So-Easy Pieces\tRichard Feynman.title: Six Not-So-Easy Pieces
Six Not-So-Easy Pieces\tRichard Feynman.author: Richard Feynman
Six Not-So-Easy Pieces\tRichard Feynman.summary: "Six lectures, all regarding the most revolutionary discovery in twentieth-century physics: Einstein's Theory of Relativity. No one--not even Einstein himself--explained these difficult, anti-intuitive concepts more clearly, or with more verve and gusto, than Feynman."

Slouching Towards Bethlehem: Essays\tJoa.title: Slouching Towards Bethlehem: Essays
Slouching Towards Bethlehem: Essays\tJoa.author: Joan Didion
Slouching Towards Bethlehem: Essays\tJoa.summary: "The first nonfiction work by one of the most distinctive prose stylists of our era, Slouching Towards Bethlehem remains, forty years after its first publication, the essential portrait of America― particularly California―in the sixties."

Snow Crash\tNeal Stephenson.title: Snow Crash
Snow Crash\tNeal Stephenson.author: Neal Stephenson
Snow Crash\tNeal Stephenson.summary: "Only once in a great while does a writer come along who defies comparison-- a writer so original he redefines the way we look at  the world. Neal Stephenson is such a writer and Snow Crash is such a novel, weaving  virtual reality, Sumerian myth, and just about everything in between with a cool, hip  cyber-sensibility to bring us the gigantic thriller of the  information age."
reviews: "It's such a great book, like, you can't give it to someone now, I've tried. You'd have to have given it to someone before you've been on the Internet. Then it changes your mind."

The Social Contract\tJean Jacques Rousse.title: The Social Contract
The Social Contract\tJean Jacques Rousse.author: Jean Jacques Rousseau
The Social Contract\tJean Jacques Rousse.summary: "Revolutionary in its own time and controversial to this day, this work is a permanent classic of political theory and a key source of democratic belief."

Sorrows of Young Werther\tJohann Wolfgan.title: Sorrows of Young Werther
Sorrows of Young Werther\tJohann Wolfgan.author: Johann Wolfgange Von Gothe
Sorrows of Young Werther\tJohann Wolfgan.summary: "An autobiographical tragic novel that follows the unhappiness of Werther after he falls desperately in love with Charlotte Buff , a young woman who is married to another."

The Story of Doctor Dolittle\tHugh Lofti.title: The Story of Doctor Dolittle
The Story of Doctor Dolittle\tHugh Lofti.author: Hugh Lofting
The Story of Doctor Dolittle\tHugh Lofti.summary: "An entertaining classic that has charmed readers of all ages for generations, Hugh Lofting's timeless tale is accompanied by 27 of his own delightful illustrations."
reviews: "Mum got it for me from the library – we could not afford new books. I read it at least twice before it had to go back."

The Storytelling Animal: How Stories Mak.title: The Storytelling Animal: How Stories Make Us Human
The Storytelling Animal: How Stories Mak.author: Jonathan Gottschall
The Storytelling Animal: How Stories Mak.summary: "Drawing on the latest research in neuroscience, psychology, and evolutionary biology, Gottschall tells us what it means to be a storytelling animal and explains how stories can change the world for the better. We know we are master shapers of story. The Storytelling Animal finally reveals how stories shape us."

The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. H.title: The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. H.author: Robert Louis Stevenson
The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. H.summary: "An intriguing combination of fantast thriller and moral allegory, The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde depicts the gripping struggle of two opposing personalities — one essentially good, the other evil — for the soul of one man."
reviews: "The classic tale of the divided self. Dr. Jekyll's noble, moral outside contains, and periodically releases, the murderous evil that is Mr. Hyde. Schizophrenia and Victorian hypocrisy coexist in a single body and cause havoc."

Stringer: A Reporter's Journey in the Co.title: Stringer: A Reporter's Journey in the Congo
Stringer: A Reporter's Journey in the Co.author: Anjan Sundaram
Stringer: A Reporter's Journey in the Co.summary: "In the powerful travel-writing tradition of Ryszard Kapuscinski and V.S. Naipaul, a haunting memoir of a dangerous and disorienting year of self-discovery in one of the world's unhappiest countries."

The Structure of Scientific Revolutions\.title: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
The Structure of Scientific Revolutions\.author: Thomas Kuhn
The Structure of Scientific Revolutions\.summary: "With The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, Kuhn challenged long-standing linear notions of scientific progress, arguing that transformative ideas don’t arise from the day-to-day, gradual process of experimentation and data accumulation but that the revolutions in science, those breakthrough moments that disrupt accepted thinking and offer unanticipated ideas, occur outside of 'normal science,' as he called it."
reviews: "Kuhn introduced the term 'paradigm shift' to describe the changeover from Ptolemaic to Copernican astronomy. But the book is far more than a classic in the history of science. It's also a book that emphasizes how what we already believe shapes what we see, what we allow ourselves to think."

The Sunday Philosophy Club\tAlexander Mc.title: The Sunday Philosophy Club
The Sunday Philosophy Club\tAlexander Mc.author: Alexander McCall Smith
The Sunday Philosophy Club\tAlexander Mc.summary: "Nothing captures the charm of Edinburgh like the bestselling Isabel Dalhousie series of novels featuring the insatiably curious philosopher and woman detective.  Whether investigating a case or a problem of philosophy, the indefatigable Isabel Dalhousie, one of fiction’s most richly developed amateur detectives, is always ready to pursue the answers to all of life’s questions, large and small."
reviews: "This book is about Applied Ethics, a subject about which the author seems to know a bit. It also makes you feel like leading a quite thinking life in Edinburgh.  I don’t want to spoil the story but I felt that I was reading a detective story until I realized what it was…"

At Swim-Two-Birds\tFlann O'Brien.title: At Swim-Two-Birds
At Swim-Two-Birds\tFlann O'Brien.author: Flann O'Brien
At Swim-Two-Birds\tFlann O'Brien.summary: "At Swim-Two-Birds is a 1939 novel by Irish writer Brian O'Nolan, writing under the pseudonym Flann O'Brien. It is widely considered to be O'Brien's masterpiece, and one of the most sophisticated examples of metafiction."
reviews: "The funniest book ever written in English (and a bit of Irish). This sustained exercise in literary parody never falters. My uncle gave it to me for Christmas when I was a teen, but I didn’t get it until my first summer as an Oxford undergraduate, when I cycled around Ireland, subsisting largely on Guinness."

Tales from the Expat Harem: Foreign Wome.title: Tales from the Expat Harem: Foreign Women in Modern Turkey
Tales from the Expat Harem: Foreign Wome.author: Anastasia Ashman
Tales from the Expat Harem: Foreign Wome.summary: "This illuminating anthology provides a window into [Turkey] from the perspective of thirty-two expatriates from seven different nations—artists, entrepreneurs, Peace Corps volunteers, archaeologists, missionaries, and others—who established lives in Turkey for work, love, or adventure."
reviews: "It is a colourful, humanistic and sincere collection of women's voices. In this book you will find cultural, social and everyday life details you wouldn’t easily encounter within the confines of mainstream academic literature. "

Tartar Steppe\tDino Buzzati.title: Tartar Steppe
Tartar Steppe\tDino Buzzati.author: Dino Buzzati
Tartar Steppe\tDino Buzzati.summary: "Often likened to Kafka's The Castle, The Tartar Steppe is both a scathing critique of military life and a meditation on the human thirst for glory."
reviews: "I never understood why the book never made it in the Anglo-Saxon world. Il deserto is one of the 20th century’s masterpieces."

Tarzan of the Apes\tEdgar Rice Burroughs.title: Tarzan of the Apes
Tarzan of the Apes\tEdgar Rice Burroughs.author: Edgar Rice Burroughs
Tarzan of the Apes\tEdgar Rice Burroughs.summary: "At Tarzan's heart rightly lies the resourceful and hunky title character, a man increasingly torn between the civil and the savage, for whom cutlery will never be less than a nightmare."
reviews: "I read it from cover to cover up my favorite tree in Danny’s garden, Beech. I fell in love with Tarzan and was very jealous when he married the wrong Jane!"

Does Technology Drive History? The Dilem.title: Does Technology Drive History? The Dilemma of Technological Determinism
Does Technology Drive History? The Dilem.author: Merritt Roe Smith
Does Technology Drive History? The Dilem.summary: "These thirteen essays explore a crucial historical question that has been notoriously hard to pin down: To what extent, and by what means, does a society's technology determine its political, social, economic, and cultural forms?"
reviews: "It’s fascinating reading because it brings together mostly historians of technology and a handful of philosophers, who approach the question of determinism from different perspectives. You have Marxist historians, economic historians, feminist historians, business historians who look at the evolution of industry, all of whom are trying to answer the question of whether certain technologies influence the course of history and if so, how?"

Temptations of Power: Islamists and Illi.title: Temptations of Power: Islamists and Illiberal Democracy in a New Middle East
Temptations of Power: Islamists and Illi.author: Shadi Hamid
Temptations of Power: Islamists and Illi.summary: "In Temptations of Power, Shadi Hamid draws on hundreds of interviews with leaders and activists from across the region to advance a new understanding of how Islamist movements change over time. He puts forward the bold thesis that repression 'forced' Islamists to moderate their politics, work in coalitions, de-emphasize Islamic law, and set aside the dream of an Islamic state. Meanwhile, democratic openings in the 1980s--and again during the Arab Spring--pushed Islamists back toward their original conservatism."

A Theory of Justice\tJohn Rawls.title: A Theory of Justice
A Theory of Justice\tJohn Rawls.author: John Rawls
A Theory of Justice\tJohn Rawls.summary: "Rawls aims to express an essential part of the common core of the democratic tradition--justice as fairness--and to provide an alternative to utilitarianism, which had dominated the Anglo-Saxon tradition of political thought since the nineteenth century."

A Theory of Power\tJeff Vail.title: A Theory of Power
A Theory of Power\tJeff Vail.author: Jeff Vail
A Theory of Power\tJeff Vail.summary: "Jeff Vail unravels the functioning of our world and proposes a core concept of patterns of power relationships. This historical critique of hierarchy sweeps from anthropology and psychology to economics and politics, ultimately presenting a model for a sustainable, human-compatible future."

They F*** You Up: How to Survive Family.title: They F*** You Up: How to Survive Family Life
They F*** You Up: How to Survive Family.author: Oliver James
They F*** You Up: How to Survive Family.summary: "In this groundbreaking book, clinical psychologist Oliver James shows that it is the way we were cared for in the first six years of life that has a crucial effect on who we are and how we behave."

This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs..title: This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. The Climate
This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs..author: Naomi Klein
This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs..summary: "In This Changes Everything Naomi Klein argues that climate change isn’t just another issue to be neatly filed between taxes and health care. It’s an alarm that calls us to fix an economic system that is already failing us in many ways."
reviews: "A remarkable account of where we are and where we need to go."

This Time Is Different: Eight Centuries.title: This Time Is Different: Eight Centuries of Financial Folly
This Time Is Different: Eight Centuries.author: Carmen Reinhart
This Time Is Different: Eight Centuries.summary: "Using clear, sharp analysis and comprehensive data, Reinhart and Rogoff document that financial fallouts occur in clusters and strike with surprisingly consistent frequency, duration, and ferocity."
reviews: "A must-read for anyone who wants to get an unemotional, untainted, no-holds-barred picture of what countries with massive debts and gaping deficits have in store economically. If the past offers any indication of the future, the U.S. and other developed economies are in for a tortuous ride."

A Thousand Days: John F. Kennedy in the.title: A Thousand Days: John F. Kennedy in the White House
A Thousand Days: John F. Kennedy in the.author: Arthur M. Schlesinger
A Thousand Days: John F. Kennedy in the.summary: "As special assistant to the president, Arthur Schlesinger witnessed firsthand the politics and personalities that influenced the now legendary Kennedy administration."

The Transformation of American Law, 1870.title: The Transformation of American Law, 1870-1960: The Crisis of Legal Orthodoxy
The Transformation of American Law, 1870.author: Morton J. Horwitz
The Transformation of American Law, 1870.summary: "In his pathbreaking first volume, Horwitz showed how economic conflicts helped transform law in antebellum America. Here, Horwitz picks up where he left off, tracing the struggle in American law between the entrenched legal orthodoxy and the Progressive movement, which arose in response to ever-increasing social and economic inequality."

Trespassing Across America: One Man's Ep.title: Trespassing Across America: One Man's Epic, Never-Done-Before (and Sort of Illegal) Hike Across the Heartland
Trespassing Across America: One Man's Ep.author: Ken Ilgunas
Trespassing Across America: One Man's Ep.summary: "Told with sincerity, humor, and wit, Trespassing Across America is both a fascinating account of one man’s remarkable journey along the Keystone XL pipeline and a meditation on climate change, the beauty of the natural world, and the extremes to which we can push ourselves—both physically and mentally."
reviews: "An epic account of walking the route of the proposed, and for the moment quashed, Keystone Pipeline."

U and I: A True Story\tNicholas Baker.title: U and I: A True Story
U and I: A True Story\tNicholas Baker.author: Nicholas Baker
U and I: A True Story\tNicholas Baker.summary: "Baker muses on the creative process via his obsession with John Updike."

Ulysses\tJames Joyce.title: Ulysses
Ulysses\tJames Joyce.author: James Joyce
Ulysses\tJames Joyce.summary: "James Joyces astonishing masterpiece, Ulysses, tells of the diverse events which befall Leopold Bloom and Stephen Dedalus in Dublin on 16 June 1904, during which Bloom's voluptuous wife, Molly, commits adultery. Initially deemed obscene in England and the USA, this richly-allusive novel, revolutionary in its Modernistic experimentalism, was hailed as a work of genius by W. B. Yeats, T. S. Eliot and Ernest Hemingway."
reviews: "It's based on one of the greatest of myths: the Odyssey transformed into the mock-epic tale of a Jewish Irish advertising salesman's cuckolded day wandering in Dublin while his faithless wife, Molly, the antithesis of Odysseus's Penelope, gets up to much nonsense in the marital bed. "

Uncommon Genius: How Great Ideas are Bor.title: Uncommon Genius: How Great Ideas are Born
Uncommon Genius: How Great Ideas are Bor.author: Denise Shekerjian
Uncommon Genius: How Great Ideas are Bor.summary: "Drawing on interviews with 40 winners of the MacArthur Foundation Fellowship—the so-called 'genius awards'—the insightful study throws fresh light on the creative process."
reviews: "A lovely book that gets into the minds of the 'genius' award winners of the MacArthur Foundation. There’s a lot to learn about ”mastery“ from these award winners and much of it can be applied to business."

Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art\.title: Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art
Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art\.author: Scott McCloud
Understanding Comics: The Invisible Art\.summary: "Praised throughout the cartoon industry by such luminaries as Art Spiegelman, Matt Groening, and Will Eisner, this innovative comic book provides a detailed look at the history, meaning, and art of comics and cartooning."
reviews: "As Scott McCloud has pointed out [...], all the action in comics happens in between the panels [...] In Panel A something happened and in Panel B something happened, but it's what happened between A and B that changed your mind about anything."

A Universe Of Consciousness: How Matter.title: A Universe Of Consciousness: How Matter Becomes Imagination
A Universe Of Consciousness: How Matter.author: Gerald Edelman
A Universe Of Consciousness: How Matter.summary: "In A Universe of Consciousness, Gerald Edelman builds on the radical ideas he introduced in his monumental trilogy-Neural Darwinism, Topobiology, and The Remembered Present-to present for the first time an empirically supported full-scale theory of consciousness."

The Universe: Leading Scientists Explore.title: The Universe: Leading Scientists Explore the Origin, Mysteries, and Future of the Cosmos
The Universe: Leading Scientists Explore.author: John Brockman
The Universe: Leading Scientists Explore.summary: "John Brockman brings together the world's best-known physicists and science writers—including Brian Greene, Walter Isaacson, Nobel Prize-winner Frank Wilczek, Benoit Mandelbrot, and Martin Rees—to explain the universe in all wondrous splendor."

The Unix Programming Environment\tBrian.title: The Unix Programming Environment
The Unix Programming Environment\tBrian.author: Brian Kernighan
The Unix Programming Environment\tBrian.summary: "Designed for first-time and experienced users, this book describes the Unix programming environment and philosophy in detail."
reviews: "In addition to its articulation of the Unix tools philosophy that is so dear to my heart, the writing is a model of clarity and elegance. As a technical writer, I aspired to be as transparent as Kernighan."

The Up Side of Down: Why Failing Well Is.title: The Up Side of Down: Why Failing Well Is the Key to Success
The Up Side of Down: Why Failing Well Is.author: Megan McArdle
The Up Side of Down: Why Failing Well Is.summary: "One of our most popular business bloggers, Megan McArdle takes insights from emergency room doctors, kindergarten teachers, bankruptcy judges, and venture capitalists to teach us how to reinvent ourselves in the face of failure."

The Vital Question: Energy, Evolution, a.title: The Vital Question: Energy, Evolution, and the Origins of Complex Life
The Vital Question: Energy, Evolution, a.author: Nick Lane
The Vital Question: Energy, Evolution, a.summary: "To explain the mystery of how life evolved on Earth, Nick Lane explores the deep link between energy and genes. Both rigorous and enchanting, The Vital Question provides a solution to life’s vital question: why are we as we are, and indeed, why are we here at all?"
reviews: "A brilliant new analysis of the origin of life, by the man who has himself done more than anybody to crack the problem. The book is full of startling, fresh insights about energy and genetics, but it’s really hard going in places, so you have to take it slowly."

Walden, or Life in the Woods\tHenry Davi.title: Walden, or Life in the Woods
Walden, or Life in the Woods\tHenry Davi.author: Henry David Thoreau
Walden, or Life in the Woods\tHenry Davi.summary: "Walden or, Life in the Woods, by noted transcendentalist Henry David Thoreau, is a reflection upon simple living in natural surroundings. The work is part personal declaration of independence, social experiment, voyage of spiritual discovery, satire, and manual for self-reliance."
reviews: "[Which nonfiction book have you reread the most times? What’s so good about it?] Walden, maybe. It's as rich and unbottomed as the Scripture"

The War of Art\tSteve Pressfield.title: The War of Art
The War of Art\tSteve Pressfield.author: Steve Pressfield
The War of Art\tSteve Pressfield.summary: "Since 2002, The War of Art has inspired people around the world to defeat Resistance; to recognize and knock down dream-blocking barriers and to silence the naysayers within us."
reviews: "This is Steve Pressfield's classic book about the Resistance and the cost of fighting it (or ignoring it). We don't need more me too from you."

Washington's War on Nicaragua\tHolly Skl.title: Washington's War on Nicaragua
Washington's War on Nicaragua\tHolly Skl.author: Holly Sklar
Washington's War on Nicaragua\tHolly Skl.summary: "Sklar shows how the White House sabotaged peace negoatiations and sustained the deadly contra war despite public opposition, with secret U.S. special forces and an auxiliary arm of dictators, drug smugglers and death squad godfathers, and illuminates an alternative policy rooted in law and democracy."

The Way of the Wizard: Twenty Spiritual.title: The Way of the Wizard: Twenty Spiritual Lessons for Creating the Life You Want
The Way of the Wizard: Twenty Spiritual.author: Deepak Chopra
The Way of the Wizard: Twenty Spiritual.summary: "The author of the acclaimed New York Times bestsellers The Seven Spiritual Laws of Success and Ageless Body, Timeless Mind now presents a guide to using spiritual alchemy for awakening the magic in everyday life."

The Weather Experiment: The Pioneers Who.title: The Weather Experiment: The Pioneers Who Sought to See the Future
The Weather Experiment: The Pioneers Who.author: Peter Moore
The Weather Experiment: The Pioneers Who.summary: "In 1865 Admiral Robert FitzRoy locked himself in his dressing room and cut his throat. His grand meteorological project had failed. Yet only a decade later, FitzRoy's storm warning system and 'forecasts' would return, the model for what we use today."
reviews: "...About the people who first invented weather forecasting in the 19th century, which I am listening to on my iPad as I fall asleep."

What Should I Do with My Life?: The True.title: What Should I Do with My Life?: The True Story of People Who Answered the Ultimate Question
What Should I Do with My Life?: The True.author: Po Bronson
What Should I Do with My Life?: The True.summary: "With humor, empathy, and insight, Bronson writes of remarkable individuals—from young to old, from those just starting out to those in a second career—who have overcome fear and confusion to find a larger truth about their lives and, in doing so, have been transformed by the experience. "

What You Can Change and What You Can't:.title: What You Can Change and What You Can't: The Complete Guide to Successful Self-Improvement
What You Can Change and What You Can't:.author: Martin Seligman
What You Can Change and What You Can't:.summary: "Martin Seligman has meticulously analyzed the most authoritative scientific research on treatments for alcoholism, anxiety, weight loss, anger, depression, and a range of phobias and obsessions to discover what is the most effective way to address each condition. He frankly reports what does not work, and pinpoints the techniques and therapies that work best for each condition, discussing why they work and how you can use them to make long lasting change."

Why Atheism?\tGeorge Smith.title: Why Atheism?
Why Atheism?\tGeorge Smith.author: George Smith
Why Atheism?\tGeorge Smith.summary: "Smith reviews the historical roots of nonbelief going back to the ancient Greeks, argues that philosophy can serve as an important alternative to religion, and defends reason as the most reliable method humans have for establishing truth and conducting one's life."

Why Evolution Is True\tJerry Coyne.title: Why Evolution Is True
Why Evolution Is True\tJerry Coyne.author: Jerry Coyne
Why Evolution Is True\tJerry Coyne.summary: "In crisp, lucid prose accessible to a wide audience, Why Evolution Is True dispels common misunderstandings and fears about evolution and clearly confirms that this amazing process of change has been firmly established as a scientific truth."
reviews: "I learned some things from his book that I hadn’t put in mine, like the fascinating fact that the genes for having a good sense of smell, which are present in a dog, are in us as well. It’s just that they’ve been turned off. Which is a fascinating vestige of an evolutionary past when our ancestors would have had a much better sense of smell."

Why Stock Markets Crash: Critical Events.title: Why Stock Markets Crash: Critical Events in Complex Financial Systems
Why Stock Markets Crash: Critical Events.author: Didier Sornette
Why Stock Markets Crash: Critical Events.summary: "Sornette probes major historical precedents, from the decades-long 'tulip mania' in the Netherlands that wilted suddenly in 1637 to the South Sea Bubble that ended with the first huge market crash in England in 1720, to the Great Crash of October 1929 and Black Monday in 1987, to cite just a few. He concludes that most explanations other than cooperative self-organization fail to account for the subtle bubbles by which the markets lay the groundwork for catastrophe."
reviews: "Honestly I don’t care for the idea of crashes; the same concepts can apply to sudden and unexpected euphorias.  I learned more from this book than any other on disequilibrium."

Churchill\tClive Ponting.title: Churchill
Churchill\tClive Ponting.author: Clive Ponting
Churchill\tClive Ponting.summary: "Ponting's text challenges the Churchill myth, declaring that much of the accepted interpretation of Churchill's life stems from his own writings about himself. Using source material released during the past 25 years, it questions his competence as a war leader and the true level of his popularity."

The Wisdom Paradox: How Your Mind Can Gr.title: The Wisdom Paradox: How Your Mind Can Grow Stronger As Your Brain Grows Older
The Wisdom Paradox: How Your Mind Can Gr.author: Elkhonon Goldberg
The Wisdom Paradox: How Your Mind Can Gr.summary: "The Wisdom Paradox explores the aging of the mind from a unique, positive perspective. In an era of increasing fears about mental deterioration, world-renowned neuropsychologist Elkhonon Goldberg provides startling new evidence that though the brain diminishes in some tasks as it ages, it gains in many ways."
reviews: "[Goldberg's] theory is that the hemispheric specialization is principally along pattern matching and information processing lines:the left side stores patterns, while the right one processes novel tasks. It is convincing to see that children suffer more from a right brain injury, while adults have the opposite effect."

Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography.title: Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography in America
Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography.author: James Allen
Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography.summary: "The Tuskegee Institute records the lynching of 3,436 blacks between 1882 and 1950."

On Writing Well: The Classic Guide to Wr.title: On Writing Well: The Classic Guide to Writing Nonfiction
On Writing Well: The Classic Guide to Wr.author: William Zinsser
On Writing Well: The Classic Guide to Wr.summary: "On Writing Well has been praised for its sound advice, its clarity and the warmth of its style. It is a book for everybody who wants to learn how to write or who needs to do some writing to get through the day, as almost everybody does in the age of e-mail and the Internet."
reviews: "I wouldn't say this book influenced me, since my principles of writing were established long before I read it. However, it does capture many things that I believe about effective writing."

Rissa Kerguelen\tFM Busby.title: Rissa Kerguelen
Rissa Kerguelen\tFM Busby.author: FM Busby
Rissa Kerguelen\tFM Busby.summary: "Living a desperate life in the Total Welfare Center, the orphan Rissa discovers she has won the lottery and takes a chance to shape her own destiny."
reviews: "A science-fiction book I read at about the time I was starting my company, and that influenced me deeply. One key idea is the role of entrepreneurship as a subversive force. In a world dominated by large companies, it is the smaller companies that keep freedom alive, with economics at least one of the battlegrounds."

Zig Ziglar’s Secrets of Closing the Sale.title: Zig Ziglar’s Secrets of Closing the Sale
Zig Ziglar’s Secrets of Closing the Sale.author: Zig Ziglar
Zig Ziglar’s Secrets of Closing the Sale.summary: "This new guide by America's #1 professional in the art of persuasion focuses on the most essential part of the sale—how to make them say 'Yes, I will!'"
reviews: "Zig Ziglar's classic book. It seems like it's filled with lessons from a door-to-door salesman, but the secrets go far deeper than that. It's about commitment and vulnerability and telling the truth."

Man and Superman\tGeorge Bernard Shaw.title: Man and Superman
Man and Superman\tGeorge Bernard Shaw.author: George Bernard Shaw
Man and Superman\tGeorge Bernard Shaw.summary: "One of Shaw’s finest and most devilish comedies, Man and Superman portrays Don Juan as the quarry instead of the huntsman."

Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the.title: Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds
Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the.author: Charles Mackay
Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the.summary: "This classic survey of crowd psychology offers an illuminating and entertaining look at three grand-scale swindles."
reviews: "[What books do you find yourself returning to again and again?] Extraordinary Delusions"

Freedom Feminism: Its Surprising History.title: Freedom Feminism: Its Surprising History and Why It Matters Today
Freedom Feminism: Its Surprising History.author: Christina Hoff Sommers
Freedom Feminism: Its Surprising History.summary: "Christina Hoff Sommers seeks to recover the lost history of American feminism by introducing readers to conservative feminism’s forgotten heroines."
reviews: "[What are the best books you’ve read about women’s rights?] Freedom Feminism"

Notes of a Native Son\tJames Baldwin.title: Notes of a Native Son
Notes of a Native Son\tJames Baldwin.author: James Baldwin
Notes of a Native Son\tJames Baldwin.summary: "This first nonfiction collection of essays by James Baldwin remains an American classic. His impassioned essays on life in Harlem, the protest novel, movies, and African Americans abroad are as powerful today as when they were first written."
reviews: "Reading this essay collection for the first time was like diving into deep waters and then suddenly surfacing: You feel the liberation of opening your eyes and seeing the sky above you. Baldwin demonstrates how to passionately articulate social and political issues and yet remain a writer, not a pamphleteer."

Electric Light\tSeamus Heaney.title: Electric Light
Electric Light\tSeamus Heaney.author: Seamus Heaney
Electric Light\tSeamus Heaney.summary: "Seamus Heaney's collection travels widely in time and space, visiting the sites of the classical world and revisiting the poet's childhood: rural electrification and the light of ancient evenings are reconciled within the orbit of a single lifetime."
reviews: "Seamus has been with me on every journey I have taken, and there have been many times when a retreat into his words has kept me afloat. Most of our life in this kind of work is very concrete, full of facts, but we all have to seek redress from time to time in poetry."

The Prophets\tAbraham Joshua Heschel.title: The Prophets
The Prophets\tAbraham Joshua Heschel.author: Abraham Joshua Heschel
The Prophets\tAbraham Joshua Heschel.summary: "The Prophets provides a unique opportunity for readers of the Old Testament, both Christian and Jewish, to gain fresh and deep knowledge of Israel's prophetic movement. The author's profound understanding of the prophets also opens the door to new insight into the philosophy of religion."
reviews: “He lays bare the roles of righteous indignation and indifference in justice.”

The Mind's I: Fantasies And Reflections.title: The Mind's I: Fantasies And Reflections On Self & Soul
The Mind's I: Fantasies And Reflections.author: Douglas Hofstadter
The Mind's I: Fantasies And Reflections.summary: "With contributions from Jorge Luis Borges, Richard Dawkins, John Searle, and Robert Nozick, The Mind's I explores the meaning of self and consciousness through the perspectives of literature, artificial intelligence, psychology, and other disciplines."
reviews: "The collection that Douglas Hofstadter and I put together more than 20 years ago, still in print and still an intellectual roller coaster of a book."

The Five Books of Moses: Genesis, Exodus.title: The Five Books of Moses: Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy
The Five Books of Moses: Genesis, Exodus.author: Everett Fox
The Five Books of Moses: Genesis, Exodus.summary: "Widely acclaimed by Bible scholars and theologians of every denomination, Everett Fox's masterful translation re-creates the echoes, allusions, alliterations, and wordplays of the Hebrew original."
reviews: "Exodus is the story of how people break free of slavery. If we can understand this myth in the way it was most likely intended, it becomes a terrific allegory for the way we enslave ourselves through the worship of false gods."

Technopoly: The Surrender of Culture to.title: Technopoly: The Surrender of Culture to Technology
Technopoly: The Surrender of Culture to.author: Neal Postman
Technopoly: The Surrender of Culture to.summary: "In this witty, often terrifying work of cultural criticism, the author of Amusing Ourselves to Death chronicles our transformation into a Technopoly: a society that no longer merely uses technology as a support system but instead is shaped by it--with radical consequences for the meanings of politics, art, education, intelligence, and truth."
reviews: "Still the simplest explanation of how new technologies get the better of us: We make a tool, we change our lives to accommodate the tool, the tool becomes our new reality. Think cars, TV, computers, smartphones..."

The Origin of Consciousness in the Break.title: The Origin of Consciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind
The Origin of Consciousness in the Break.author: Julian Jaynes
The Origin of Consciousness in the Break.summary: "At the heart of this classic, seminal book is Julian Jaynes's still-controversial thesis that human consciousness did not begin far back in animal evolution but instead is a learned process that came about only three thousand years ago and is still developing."
reviews: "Jaynes makes a good case for the theory that human beings, in an earlier state of brain evolution, used to 'hear' the voice of God."

Turbulent Mirror: An Illustrated Guide t.title: Turbulent Mirror: An Illustrated Guide to Chaos Theory and the Science of Wholeness
Turbulent Mirror: An Illustrated Guide t.author: John Briggs
Turbulent Mirror: An Illustrated Guide t.summary: "With practical applications ranging from the control of traffic flow and the development of artifical intelligence to the treatment of heart attacks and schizophrenia, chaos promises to be an increasingly rewarding area of inquiry -- of interest to everyone."
reviews: "This is my own personal favourite book explaining fractals and chaos."

The Diamond in Your Pocket: Discovering.title: The Diamond in Your Pocket: Discovering Your True Radiance
The Diamond in Your Pocket: Discovering.author: Gangaji
The Diamond in Your Pocket: Discovering.summary: "In The Diamond in Your Pocket, Gangaji describes our never-ending search as human beings to find fulfillment―which, paradoxically, already exists if only we will stop long enough to experience it."

The Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are.title: The Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are Divided by Politics and Religion
The Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are.author: Jonathan Haidt
The Righteous Mind: Why Good People Are.summary: "Drawing on his twenty five years of groundbreaking research on moral psychology, Haidt shows how moral judgments arise not from reason but from gut feelings. He shows why liberals, conservatives, and libertarians have such different intuitions about right and wrong, and he shows why each side is actually right about many of its central concerns."
reviews: "A brilliant mixture of political philosophy and sociology. According to Haidt, two reasonable people can find themselves on opposite ends of the political spectrum based on the relative importance each assigns to just six values. "

One Pair of Hands\tMonica Dickens.title: One Pair of Hands
One Pair of Hands\tMonica Dickens.author: Monica Dickens
One Pair of Hands\tMonica Dickens.summary: "Dickens' keen eye for detail, youthful resilience, and sense of the absurd make One Pair of Hands a deliciously inside look at the households of the British upper-class."

The Miracle of Life\tMerce Parramon.title: The Miracle of Life
The Miracle of Life\tMerce Parramon.author: Merce Parramon
The Miracle of Life\tMerce Parramon.summary: "Investigates nature's hidden processes -- Outlines the most important functions of the human body and plant life in fascinating detail."
reviews: "It was not a book intended for children, but it was my bible and I spent hours studying and learning from it."

The Rime of the Ancient Mariner\tSamuel.title: The Rime of the Ancient Mariner
The Rime of the Ancient Mariner\tSamuel.author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

Don't Sleep, There Are Snakes\tDaniel L..title: Don't Sleep, There Are Snakes
Don't Sleep, There Are Snakes\tDaniel L..author: Daniel L. Everett
reviews: "The author lived among Brazil's Pirahã Indians to convert them to Christianity. Instead the Pirahã's unshakably realistic outlook rendered them immune to Everett's conversion efforts and eventually caused him to give up his own belief in a Christian God."

We, the Navigators\tDavid Lewis.title: We, the Navigators
We, the Navigators\tDavid Lewis.author: David Lewis
reviews: "How did Polynesians and other Pacific Islanders navigate sailing canoes for thousands of miles without a compass and discover every tropical Pacific island? Lewis learned the fascinating answers by sailing with one of the last of those traditional navigators."

How Much Is Enough?\tRobert Skidelsky.title: How Much Is Enough?
How Much Is Enough?\tRobert Skidelsky.author: Robert Skidelsky
reviews: "The book has not yet received the wide attention it deserves, but I found the way it applies to some of Keynes's boldest ideas about economics and the good life thought-stirring and extremely refreshing."

The Hockey Stick Illusion\tAndrew Montfo.title: The Hockey Stick Illusion
The Hockey Stick Illusion\tAndrew Montfo.author: Andrew Montford
reviews: "It’s a great piece of detective work on a key scientific blunder, based around the work of Steve McIntyre and Ross McKitrick, and it forensically dismantles the mistakes that led to people believing they had at last found evidence that current climate change is unprecedented in rate or scale in this millennium."

What You Want\tConstantine Phipps.title: What You Want
What You Want\tConstantine Phipps.author: Constantine Phipps
reviews: "A delightful verse novel about philosophy by a friend of mine."

Financial Derivatives\tJamil Baz.title: Financial Derivatives
Financial Derivatives\tJamil Baz.author: Jamil Baz
reviews: "No financial book has the clarity of this text."

Good Calories, Bad Calories\tGary Taubes.title: Good Calories, Bad Calories
Good Calories, Bad Calories\tGary Taubes.author: Gary Taubes
reviews: "Gary Taubes is a true empiricist. I can’t believe people hold on to the Platonicity of the thermodynamic theory of diet (calorie in = calorie out)."

How Nature Works: The Science of Self-Or.title: How Nature Works: The Science of Self-Organized Criticality
How Nature Works: The Science of Self-Or.author: Per Bak
reviews: "This book is a great attempt at finding some universality based on systems in a 'critical' state, with departures from such state taking place in a manner that follows power laws. The sandpile is a great baby model for that."

Intellectuals in the Middle Ages\tJacque.title: Intellectuals in the Middle Ages
Intellectuals in the Middle Ages\tJacque.author: Jacques Le Goff
reviews: "Excellent, be it only for the presentation of the difference between the pompous scholastic thinker laboring in the academy and the other nonacademic humanist laboring in the the 'luxe calme et volupte' of his study."

Kant and the Platypus\tUmberto Eco.title: Kant and the Platypus
Kant and the Platypus\tUmberto Eco.author: Umberto Eco
reviews: "When I started reading the book I was taken aback by the combination of depth and the vividness of the style. Eco is sprightly and alive, something that cannot be said of many philosophers dealing with the subject of categories."

Mapping the Mind\tRita Carter.title: Mapping the Mind
Mapping the Mind\tRita Carter.author: Rita Carter
reviews: "I read here and there comments by neuroscientists dissing the book over small details perhaps invisible even to experts. I just realize that Carter should keep updating it, as it is invaluable in my suitcase when I travel! I do not conceal my suspicion of 'science writers' and journalists more trained in communicating than understanding and usually shallow babblers but Carter is an exception."

Mean Genes\tTerry Burnham.title: Mean Genes
Mean Genes\tTerry Burnham.author: Terry Burnham
reviews: "The book is so readable as to perhaps set a standard. Yet it is complete in the sense that it covers more of the evolutionary thinking than meets the eye. I didn’t realize it until I went to the site www.meangenes.org and got into the more technical research material. Reread it."

Modern Aramaic-English/English-Modern Ar.title: Modern Aramaic-English/English-Modern Aramaic Dictionary & Phrasebook: Assyrian/Syriac
Modern Aramaic-English/English-Modern Ar.author: Nicholas Awde
reviews: "This book in the Latin alphabet makes both Swadaya and Turoyo alive and easy to read, with all manner of real-world expressions. One can use it to supplement scholarly studies, or just to figure out how modern people speak our ancient language."

No Bull\tMichael Steinhardt.title: No Bull
No Bull\tMichael Steinhardt.author: Michael Steinhardt
reviews: "The man is one of the greatest traders in history. There are a few jewels in there."

Probability, Random Variables, and Stoch.title: Probability, Random Variables, and Stochastic Processes
Probability, Random Variables, and Stoch.author: Athanasios Papoulis
reviews: "When readers and students ask to me for a useable book for nonmathematicians to get into probability (or a probabilistic approach to statistics), before embarking into deeper problems, I suggest this book by the Late A. Papoulis."

Statistical Models\tDavid Freeman.title: Statistical Models
Statistical Models\tDavid Freeman.author: David Freeman
reviews: "This book is outstanding in the following two aspects: 1) It is of immense clarity, embedding everything in real situations, 2) It uses the real-life situation to critique the statistical model and show you the limit of statistic."

Straw Dogs\tJohn Gray.title: Straw Dogs
Straw Dogs\tJohn Gray.author: John Gray
reviews: "What struck me with this book is that Gray converges in opinion to the discoveries of the New Science of Man –without quoting from neurobiology, cognitive science, evolutionary psychology, the Kahneman-Tversky Heuristics & Biases Tradition."

The (Mis)behavior of Markets\tBenoit Man.title: The (Mis)behavior of Markets
The (Mis)behavior of Markets\tBenoit Man.author: Benoit Mandelbrot
reviews: "Mandelbrot brought fractals into mathematics by going to the general public. He is doing the same here: pleading to the regular man unburdened with knowledge of economics."

The Discovery of France\tGraham Robb.title: The Discovery of France
The Discovery of France\tGraham Robb.author: Graham Robb
reviews: "This is the most profound examination of how nationality is enforced on a group of people, with the internal colonization process and the stamping out of idiosyncratic traits."

The Dream of Reason\tAnthony Gottlieb.title: The Dream of Reason
The Dream of Reason\tAnthony Gottlieb.author: Anthony Gottlieb
reviews: "I could not put it down. It hit me at some point that I was at the intersection of readability and scholarship. Clearly the value of this book lies beyond its readability: Gottlieb is both a philosopher and a journalist (in the good sense), not a journalist who writes about philosophy. "

The Hour Between Dog & Wolf\tJohn Coates.title: The Hour Between Dog & Wolf
The Hour Between Dog & Wolf\tJohn Coates.author: John Coates
reviews: "Great book. I ignored the connection to financial markets while reading it. But I learned that when under stress, one should seek the familiar. Bravo!"

The Making of a Philosopher\tColin McGin.title: The Making of a Philosopher
The Making of a Philosopher\tColin McGin.author: Colin McGinn
reviews: "Colin McGINN teaches us that we need nevertheless to master the art of clarity of both thought and exposition. He write with perfect clarity: a clear, unburdened, unaffected, UnFrench UnGerman philosophical prose."

The Mind Doesn't Work That Way\tJerry Fo.title: The Mind Doesn't Work That Way
The Mind Doesn't Work That Way\tJerry Fo.author: Jerry Fodor
reviews: "This critique of the computational theory of mind and the pan-adaptionist tradition is clearly so honest that it goes after the ideas promoted by Fodor’s own 1983 watershed book The Modularity of Mind."

The Science of Conjecture\tJames Frankli.title: The Science of Conjecture
The Science of Conjecture\tJames Frankli.author: James Franklin
reviews: "This book stands above, way above the rest: I’ve never seen a deeper exposition of the subject, as this text covers, in addition to the mathematical bases, the true philosophical origin of the notion of probability."

The Status Syndrome\tMichael Marmot.title: The Status Syndrome
The Status Syndrome\tMichael Marmot.author: Michael Marmot
reviews: "You are a hot shot in a company, though not the boss. You are paid extremely well, but, again you have plenty of bosses above you (say the partners of an investment firm). Is it better than deriving a modest income being your own boss? The counterintuive answer is NO. You will live longer in the second situation, even controlling for diet, lifestyle, and genetic predispositions.  Marmot spent years poring over data; he left no stone unturned and is well read in the general literature on human nature. This idea of people living longer when they exert control over their lives has not spread yet."

Thinking and Deciding\tJonathan Baron.title: Thinking and Deciding
Thinking and Deciding\tJonathan Baron.author: Jonathan Baron
reviews: "I am buying another copy of this book as mine was lost or misplaced. That should speak volumes."

Tyranny of Experts\tWilliam Easterly.title: Tyranny of Experts
Tyranny of Experts\tWilliam Easterly.author: William Easterly
reviews: "The point that top-down development methods are great on paper but have not produced benefits ('so far') is a point Easterly has made before, heavily influencing yours truly in the formation his own argument against naive interventionism."

Why Everyone (Else) Is a Hypocrite\tRobe.title: Why Everyone (Else) Is a Hypocrite
Why Everyone (Else) Is a Hypocrite\tRobe.author: Robert Kurzban

Gold and Iron\tFritz Stern.title: Gold and Iron
Gold and Iron\tFritz Stern.author: Fritz Stern
reviews: "We all need role models, and when I started to work on financial history, this book, about 'Bismarck, Bleichröder, and the Building of the German Empire,' was mine. Seldom, if ever, has the financial back story of great historical events been so brilliantly illuminated."

Final Exit\tDerek Humphrey.author: Derek Humphrey
reviews: "Unlike all the other books on this list, this is one that I hope you'll never want to read. But if the day comes when you need to be in control of how your life ends, and you can't find a doctor who will help, this is the book to get."

Humanity\tJonathan Glover.title: Humanity
Humanity\tJonathan Glover.author: Jonathan Glover
reviews: "A philosopher's look at the moral history of the 20th century, full of remarkable information and wise reflections."

On Liberty\tJS Mill.title: On Liberty
On Liberty\tJS Mill.author: JS Mill
reviews: "Mill's defence of individual liberty and freedom of expression is a model of political argument, and a pleasure to read."

Pride & Prejudice\tJane Austen.title: Pride & Prejudice
Pride & Prejudice\tJane Austen.author: Jane Austen
reviews: "If this is not the best novel ever written, I don't know what surpasses it for fine observation of manners, character and passions, all told with the most delightfully delicate sense of humour."

Silent Spring\tRachel Carson.title: Silent Spring
Silent Spring\tRachel Carson.author: Rachel Carson
reviews: "Probably the most important book on the environment ever written, and once you read it, it is easy to see why."

The Descent of Man\tCharles Darwin.title: The Descent of Man
The Descent of Man\tCharles Darwin.author: Charles Darwin
reviews: "Together with Darwin's The Origin of Species - and a better read - this book ushered in the modern understanding of what we are, and our relationship to other animals."

The Methods of Ethics\tHenry Sidgwick.title: The Methods of Ethics
The Methods of Ethics\tHenry Sidgwick.author: Henry Sidgwick
reviews: "After 100 years, this remains the most careful, thorough and accurate study of ethics I know."

Samarkand\tAmin Maalouf.title: Samarkand
Samarkand\tAmin Maalouf.author: Amin Maalouf
reviews: "Though written in French, this historical novel by the inimitable Lebanese novelist Amin Maalouf is a masterpiece that I try to read at least once a year. The double narrative intercuts the story of the great poet and mystic Omar Khayyam, who composed the Rubaiyat in the 12th century, with the adventures of an American scholar on the hunt for Khayyam’s lost manuscript in the 20th century."

The Day the Leader Was Killed\tNaguib Ma.title: The Day the Leader Was Killed
The Day the Leader Was Killed\tNaguib Ma.author: Naguib Mahfouz
reviews: "The Nobel Prize–winning novelist has written dozens of internationally renowned books. But this compact novella, which chronicles the lives of a middle-class family in Cairo in the years leading up to the assassination of Egyptian President Anwar Sadat, remains as timely a story today as it was when Mahfouz wrote it in 1985."

The Secret Life of Saeed the Pessoptimis.title: The Secret Life of Saeed the Pessoptimist
The Secret Life of Saeed the Pessoptimis.author: Emile Habiby
reviews: "Habiby’s dreamy, darkly comic 1974 novel—about a dim-witted Palestinian peasant who works as an informer for the Israeli government and is suddenly abducted by an alien—remains one of the greatest works of satire in Arabic literature. It also offers a new and absolutely hilarious way of looking at the absurd tragedy of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict."

Evolution of Cooperation\tRobert Axelrod.title: Evolution of Cooperation
Evolution of Cooperation\tRobert Axelrod.author: Robert Axelrod
reviews: "The world’s leaders should all be locked up with this book and not released until they have read it. This would be a pleasure to them and might save the rest of us."

Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thin.title: Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thinking
Intuition Pumps and Other Tools for Thin.author: Daniel Dennett
reviews: "I once heard of a philosopher who gushed an 'Oh, thank you!' when a woman at a party said she found his book hard to understand. Dennett is the opposite. He works hard at being understood, and makes brilliant use of intuition pumps (his own coining) to that end. "

Red Strangers\tElspeth Huxley.title: Red Strangers
Red Strangers\tElspeth Huxley.author: Elspeth Huxley
reviews: "This epic saga sweeping through four generations of life among Kenya's Kikuyu tribe is a novel of Steinbeckian stature neglected by literary connoisseurs. Huxley leads us into the Kikuyu world so that, when the British arrive, they seem as alien as invading Martians. Her descriptive powers rival Steinbeck's, but her imagery is drawn from the Kikuyu mind. A felled tree 'tottered like a drunken elder.'"

Splendid Isolation\tGeorge Gaylord Simps.title: Splendid Isolation
Splendid Isolation\tGeorge Gaylord Simps.author: George Gaylord Simpson
reviews: "A particularly fascinating case study in evolution [that] illustrates principles that are true anywhere in the world."

The Ant and the Peacock\tHelena Cronin.title: The Ant and the Peacock
The Ant and the Peacock\tHelena Cronin.author: Helena Cronin
reviews: "It’s a book on the history of ideas showing how a divergence that began in the 19th century persists even to this day, and it’s a beautifully written book."

The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Ca.title: The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Candle in the Dark
The Demon-Haunted World: Science as a Ca.author: Carl Sagan
reviews: "You'd expect this bible of scientific skepticism to be dry, cold, Gradgrindian even. Instead it is poetic, imaginative, tinted with Carl Sagan's wonder at the magic of reality, the poetry of the real world, which is science."

Uncle Fred in the Springtime\tPG Wodehou.title: Uncle Fred in the Springtime
Uncle Fred in the Springtime\tPG Wodehou.author: PG Wodehouse
reviews: "P.G. Wodehouse is my escape from the sleep-disturbing troubles of life. I know all too exactly what Evelyn Waugh meant when he said, 'Wodehouse's idyllic world can never stale. He will continue to release future generations from captivity that may be more irksome than our own.' I love Jeeves and Bertie, but Uncle Fred teamed up with Lord Emsworth provides perhaps the purest release of all."

He began his first chapter: 'Some of the evil of my tale may have been inherent in our circumstances.'
